Comment: This is the second game I want to show from our Gruenfeld mini-tournament (the first was my loss to "superpom"), and again the d-pawn is decisive. Fortunately I have the White pieces this time.
A small mistake - and even right out of the opening. Thematic is c7-c5 to challenge the White center.

Wrong square for the Knight! 11. - Nc6 would still give White a slight plus, but now the b7 pawn can be taken for free. After 11. - Nc6 12. Be3 The pawn could be protected by 12. - Na5.

And the d-pawn is on its way again ...

And the d-pawn is on its way again ...

Let us stop and make some status: Black has lost the Bishop pair (not un-important in an open game like the Gruenfeld), has lost a pawn, and the Bg7 looks very passive. White will put pressure on the isolated a- and c-pawns, protect the passed pawn on d5 with Rd1 and get the two Bishops to better placements. Frankly, I hate to play Black in this opening line, but of course it is just a matter of taste.

Of course White will not allow it, and now the d-pawn causes havoc once again. Roughly speaking Black is lost already.

In a lost position is is hard to give good advise, but Black had a little trick up his sleeve if he had played: 25. - Rd8!? Then 26. dxe7???? Rxd1+ ending up with a Bishops endgame and good chances for Black. But of course White can just play 26. Bxc5 Qe6 27. Rd5 followed by c3-c4.

? The same as resignation, but after 26. - Rc7 27. Bg5 will be devastating. Black held on for a few more moves.

There is a forced mate in eight moves. I hope the theme around the advanced d-pawn will provide you with some inspiration if you try your luck in the Gruenfeld.
